description:
Not to be confused with divinatory tarot, the game of tarot probably comes from Italy. It is played with a 78-card deck that has 56 suited cards (similar to the 52-card Poker deck, with the addition of a Cavalier or Knight court card between the Jack and Queen in each suit), plus 21 suitless trump cards in ascending rank, and one "Fool", similar to the Joker but with differing origins.

In the most popular tarot game, called French Tarot in most English-speaking countries, one of the players will be the taker who will be playing against all the other players. The takers' goal is to make a certain amount of points in order to fulfill the contract which the taker player bids on at the beginning of the game. The goal of the other players (called the defense) is to stop the taker from achieving their score. The defense plays as a team against the taker.

After receiving their hand, the players will take turns betting on a contract based on whether they think they can achieve the number of points required. The last player to place a bet will become the taker.

A large number of European card games are played with either the full tarot deck or a subset of it, often re-faced in Germanic or other Eastern European motifs.

Card game similar to Touring was published in a form fitting box with 75 cards:  39 mileage, 10 take off, 10 weather, 15 hazards and 1 Lucky Lindy.  Based on the historic flight of the same year, hazards include forced landing, storm,  fog, engine trouble, etc.

Inventor was a flier in the US Navy and also made gliders and models.

Came out in the same year as the similar game Lindy, the New Flying Game by Parker Bros., apparently the subject of a lawsuit by Nucraft against Parker Bros which the latter won. This caused the Nucraft game to have a far more limited production and thus their game is far more valuable to collectors today. 

     Not so sure about this interpretation. A note on the rules for
     Nucraft's game Crash game indicate that Parker Brothers bought
     the rights to the Lindy game from Nucraft. So it would seem
     that Parker bought out Nucraft and shelved their version of
     the game.

After the lawsuit Nucraft issued a different game called Crash, The New Airplane Game. It seems to be a Parcheesi type game played with three planes per color and a four color spinner.

Nucraft Toys ended in 1933 when the company started operating under the name of its founder Paul K. Guillow.  The company Paul K. Guillow did not produce any games.

Players use over-sized cards to "join" partners' body parts- elbows, heads, legs, or feet.  Partners take turns drawing cards which identify the body parts to join and the partners must do so without causing existing cards to drop.  The card must be kept between the two body parts at all times. Partners are eliminated if they allow 2 cards to fall.

Play 9 holes of golf on a simulated course using dice.  On the board each hole is divided into regions which require you to use a certain club.  The roll of the dice cross-referenced with the club determines where your ball goes next.

A simple card-based memory game. 21 cards showing two hand images in various colors are spread out on the table. On his turn, a player rolls a die and covers a hand image of the matching color. If he covers the last uncovered image on a card, he must announce the color of the other, previously covered, image. If he's correct, he gets the card as a point. If not, his turn ends and the next player takes his turn. Play continues until only 5 cards are left. Most cards won wins the game.

Abstract war/strategy game. Each player has one row of pieces deployed at one side of an 8x9 grid. An elastic band divides the board. Pieces move vertically and horizontally with the objective of placing one piece in the opponents back row. The gimmick is pieces can be eliminated by stretching the elastic band (the boundary) around an opponents piece(s) which eliminates that piece and causes the boundary to change (as that piece is removed from play).

Run Hippy! Run!The Boardgame is the game of capitalism let loose on the globe. As a Captain of Industry, you will exploit the people and resources of the world to advance your corporation, all the while plotting to crush any dissent.

Gameplay consists of moving around a board and collecting profitable Corporate Misconduct Cards and costly (but useful) Tactic Cards. Use your Tactic Cards to catch and crush that spirit of dissent, the Hippy.

The entire game is available FREE in 4 PDFs through the Puzzling Evidence website (see link below).

A version of the traditional game "Yacht" (an English version of Generala).

This game has several rule and scoring differences from Yahtzee, which was based on "Yacht".

Players are rock stars and collect gold records to win. Roll dice to spiral in the player counters from the start to end square on the board. Squares have events for players to collect or lose money or release an album, which may turn out to be a hit, a dud, or break-even. Game comes with a 45 RPM record which must be played when any album is released. A random track determines the success of the album.

LOSER is a party game where players move around the board based on their responses to questions about bad behavior, bad judgment, and just plain bad luck.  The colors on the board and the roll of the dice add an element of "Loser's Luck" to the game.  A social game with lots of embarrassing storytelling.  Because we've all done things we're not proud of.

Articulation is a word game that can be played either individually or in teams.

The five categories in the game are slang, jargon, word origins, spelling, and vocabulary. The cards, except spelling, are multiple-choice.

In Articulation, the player with the best vocabulary will not always win… The game has been designed to provide a level playing field. Duel squares, stop squares, and free roll squares are but some of the equalizing factors in Articulation.

A trivia game where gameplay is extremely similar to 'Trivial Pursuit'. Main difference is all questions deal with quotes made by famous people. All questions are multiple choice, and players must 'fill in the blank' from a quote read from the question card.

In the land of ancient Greece, called Hellas, the people waged power struggles for control of the many valuable islands. The combatants faced each other over land and across the seas. In these battles with sail and sword, the combatants venture forth to discover new islands to fight over. To aid them in their battles, the combatants often seek the favor of the Gods.

Hellas FAQ

Hellas is part of the Kosmos two-player series.

In this game, the players try to earn wooden sticks by advancing colored beavers on spaces of matching color. The board is set on balance on a wooden piece. When moving a beaver, you have to carefully choose the right one, so as to not let the board fall.

Thud! is an abstract game based on Terry Pratchett's DISCWORLD saga, more specifically on the epic Battle of Koom Valley between the Dwarfs and the Trolls. The players play on a 165 octagonal shaped board as either the Dwarfs or the Trolls. The 8 Trolls start the game in the middle of the board as they have been ambushed by 32 Dwarves (surrounding them at the outer edge of the board). Trolls and Dwarves have different ways of moving and capturing. Each battle is ended by mutual agreement and then scored. When the first battle is over, the players switch sides. The combined scores from both battles determines the winner.

Thud! is similar to Hnefatafl but is not actually a member of the tafl family (See http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgamefamily/4049/tafl) because the manner of capture has been modernized and the game involves no king piece.

In Rays of Light, each player sets up colored chips and chips representing mirrors on their grid, which is hidden from their opponent, much like in Battleship.  The object is to guess what your opponent's grid looks like, by shooting imaginary light rays into the grid.  Your opponent will tell you where on the grid the light exited, and what color it was.  Using this information, you try to recreate your opponent's grid before he does the same.

Rays of Light could be described as a combination of Battleship and Black Box.

Baston is a humorous skirmish fighting board-wargame which takes place in a suburban French bar. Each player manages a gang of bad boys fighting with bottles of beer and moto chains.

Illustrated by Franck Margerin (a well known French cartoonist), Baston is one of the earliest games of Bruno Faidutti.

From the back of the box description:

Sail with the Pilgrims in 1620 across the storm-tossed Atlantic as they seek their new home in America. Make another journey next year with ships bearing new settlers and supplies for the hard-pressed colony. Storms, ice, fog, pirates and uncertainty will make for an exciting voyage as you race to land your life-saving supplies.

Designed for 1-4 players Ages 10 and up, The Voyage of the Mayflower also has a unique solo version. The 8-page Game Book includes the rules of play, the story of the voyage, life aboard ship, a list of supplies and provisions, and educational notes. Also included is a decorative frameable print of the Mayflower passenger list.

Based on the NBC TV show.

Players secretly write an answer to a "loaded" question in their Secret Answer Cover. The Master of Ceremonies then reads these answers aloud.

The object is to score points by guessing correctly who wrote each answer.

Created for the American Cancer Society, the objective is to collect the most money for the ACS by:
(1) Collecting cards to spell CRUSADE, and trading each letter for higher value versions to maximize the worth of the word, and
(2) Answering  questions about cancer and ACS.

The player with the most money wins.

Cradle of Civilization is a 2-7 player game which blends Diplomatic, Military, and Economic mechanisms to produce an exciting game system for both the casual gamer and the experienced hobbyist. Players control the destinies of the world's major cultures from 800 B.C. onwards. Each turn lasts 100 years, with players controlling  the Armies and Economies of their respective Civilizations.

By utilizing skillful diplomacy and military strategy a player can achieve world-wide pre-eminence for his Civilization.

Using a spinner to randomly select which action you must take this turn, each player attempts to assemble their jigsaw puzzle depicting a fossilized dinosaur.

Actions direct the player to buy, trade or draw a "bone" (puzzle piece) or take a card of a random event deck.

1000 Blank White Cards is a public domain card game, which allows the players to make the cards during the course of the game. There are no initial rules, and while there may be conventions among certain groups of players, it is in the spirit of the game to spite and denounce these conventions, as well as to adhere to them religiously.

Card Content

Cards may feature a title, a picture, a score, a rule, or any other content, and need not be limited to one side or even to a single card. Early iterations of the game included cards with attached objects, and cards of a variety of sizes and shapes within the same deck and gameplay session. Many cards in later decks have a point value, but this is by no means a requirement.

Cards generally include hand-drawn pictures. The game encourages quick sketches by non-artists, which can add to the overall ironic orientation of the game. Card illustrations can represent anything the designer wants to feature, from serious to absurd. (However, usually cards tend toward the latter.)

Game Play

Game play conventionally follows a "draw one, play one" rule, with standard rotation; however, this, as with any game parameters, can be arbitrarily altered in play.

In one variant, blank cards are simply made available to all players at all times, and can be created without limitation and played in turn. In other variants, players seed an otherwise blank deck with their own invented cards, which are shuffled in with blank cards to form a deck of about 60-90 cards. In this latter variant, a player may only craft a new card if he or she draws one of the blank cards during the course of play.

In most cases, unless countermanded or constrained by rules created during gameplay, players may play a card on themselves, on another player, or on all players. Card rules and actions may counter other cards which have already been played.

The game ends when the deck is exhausted. Points may be tabulated and a winner declared. In some variants, players may then lay out all of the cards face-up for the "epilogue", which allows players to choose the best cards to seed the deck for the next game. In other variants, all cards must be retained and reintroduced, regardless of perceived quality.

Similar to:

    Dvorak
    Nomic

The board shows a town from the Wild West. In it are foundations for six buildings, a jail and central plaza. Pawns represent Zorro and five other players (bandits). There is also a mask to obscure the vision of the Zorro player. Despite being dressed in black, Zorro is a good guy and must capture the bandits. Each bandit gets 3 cards. Buildings are placed on the foundation spots and the bandits attempt to rob them. Zorro dons his mask and the others take turns silently placing their pawns in the buildings of their choice. Then Zorro chooses his location. Using cards the players are able to move and engage in their activities.  Whoever has the most success wins.

This chess-like variant is themed around the military formations used by the Ancient Greeks. Each player has 15 identical pieces that are set up on opposite sides of the board, which is comprised of an 8×8 playing field of squares that is further divided diagonally in alternate fashion (see picture). Pieces are comprised of 8 small triangles of various orientation (Auxiliaries), 4 squares (Archers) which are the size of two Auxiliaries, 2 Hoplites (which are the size of an Archer with an Auxiliary on top), and 1 Syntagma, a larger triangle (the size of 2 Auxiliaries combined). Since each piece must always be oriented to face its owner (diagram for set-up is printed on the board), you’ll find that some pieces are not interchangeable with others of the same type (like Hoplites and Auxiliaries). This is important as all movement is done by moving pieces diagonally, horizontally, or vertically without rotation along paths that are not blocked and the piece must end on a space where the board outline matches the piece.

The object of the game is to capture or "Phalanx" your opponents pieces—not by jumping (as in Checkers) or by taking its place on the board (as in Chess), but by surrounding it on two of its sides with your pieces (custodial capture, as in Hnefatafl). A multiple Phalanx attack is possible if a move surrounds several of the opponent’s pieces at once. When 14 of a player’s 15 pieces are captured, that player can no longer win and is eliminated. Tied or drawn games (you can play to a time limit as well) are determined by the value of each player’s remaining pieces, which range between 5 and 20 points each.

This is a solitaire game involving tank command-- that is you control a Sherman tank (17 variations) and command a crew assigned to the 4th Armored Division as you move out of the "Cobra Breakout" following the Normandy invasion.

You and your tank move into a new territory and deal with German defenses situated in northern France and, as the campaign game goes on, across the Rhine and into Germany.  You will need to make life and death decisions in managing your crew's actions, your tank's facing, and attempt to take out enemy forces without losing your tank (which is extremely challenging).  The combat system utilizes an "area map" for the larger scale movement of your "task force" but then cleverly switches to an abstracted "Battle Board" when contact is made with the enemy. Many time you are ambushed. Sometimes you are the "lead tank" and draw the enemies fire. Other times you may actually have some High Velocity Armor Piercing loaded in your gun when you meet up with that Tiger lurking over the hill...

For those of you who like to roll percentile dice --this game's for you!

The crisscross Rummy game -- a fast action rummy board game where players compete on as many as nine "hands" at once.

Plays similarly to Scrabble on a 15x15 board.  Each person has seven tiles representing cards in a standard deck and must score as many points as possible by playing the tiles to the board to form gin rummy melds.

The game consists of a race through a board with coloured spaces and 6 books with questions of 6 categories (Science, entertainment, history / geography, sports, art and trade). The player / team roll the dice to get 3 numbers, for example 3-1-6. Then, from the book with the color of the space landed, other player reads the question number 316. If the player answers correctly, he can continue playing, otherwise the next player continues. When a player guesses the answer of a space with a star, he receives a token of the color associated with the topic answered correctly. The first to get a token from each category wins!

The game includes a cardboard with 12 areas, 30 counters
that figure gorillas, sheets for orders and a dice.
Each player secretly chooses one gorilla, and his goal will be to climb to the highest hierarchy level in his group
of gorillas.
During the game, each player secretly writes orders for specific gorilla(s), which will be resolved simultaneously.
These orders relate to natural activities of gorillas; the dice are used to determine the results of some activities,
as conflicts.

Part of the American Adventure series.

1903 automobile race from San Francisco to New York.

Players move a space and then spin to see what happens to them.

Intended for Ages 8 and up.
Minor modification of the original Rack-O, with new cards (Draw 2, Wild) and special rules for some of the number cards.

Write 10 words using a Wordster, a special 3-letter combination. If the Wordster is ITE, you can write bITE, kITE, ITEm, lIsTEn or whIsTlE [whistle]!

Keep the letters together or spread them out. As long as the letters are in order these words count.

Now declare your words and compare words with your opponents. You get a point for every word you have that no other opponent does. But if a word is repeated then the first player to claim it gets 2 points and the others get nothing.

Chess for three players. Also includes Megacheckers on the flip side of the board.

When the other two players have resigned or their king has been checkmated, the third player wins.

A version of a popular dictionary game, players use the enclosed dictionary of slang and make up definitions of the given word. The real definition is included and players score points by guessing which is which.

In Dealing with Murder - Fatal Error , 2-6 players get together to try and solve a murder mystery. Each player is dealt a hand of 3 cards that comes from a deck of cards where each card is unique, and has either has some information pertaining to the mystery, or has actions that a player can take. Each turn a player plays a card (reveals evidence) to the discard pile where everyone can read the information. The cards a player keeps in his hand are considered 'withheld evidence'. A player may also play a subpoena card to look at all the cards in a given players hand or to increase their own hand size. Play continues like this until a player thinks they can solve the mystery. They announce their solution (Who, Motive, How) and then reads (silently) the solution. If correct, they win, if not, they are out of the game and play continues.

Game is (very slightly) compared to the 'How to Host Your Own Murder' series, in that once the game is played, it cannot be played again by the same players, as there is only one solution.

The box even references said product, by stating that to play 'Dealing with Murder', you don't need to cook a dinner or show up wearing a costume to play.

Players draw hands of tiles with color and number and arrow markings.

Much like in the card-based UNO, each player must play the next tile that matches either the color or number of the previous one played. However in UNO Wild Tiles, they must play it on the space indicated by the arrow on the previous tile, and may place their own tile so that the arrow suits them.

Winner is the first to clear their rack, or the person with the fewest points when it is impossible to play any more tiles.

Each player starts with 6 part of a meal (drink, fish, meat, sweet, etc.). On your turn, you can turn a card revealing a dirty dish in one of the 4 colors, or stacking one of your cards (or stack of cards) on one with the same dish or the same color. The loser of the game is the one with the most dishes at the end. He's the one who will clean the dishes... The glove is included!

The components for this game consist of 18 plastic hex tiles in each of 5 colors - each player gets 16 blank tiles, one King, and one Warrior.  In the initial phase of the game, players place these tiles on the table (there is no board) in one connected group, but are not allowed to connect more than 5 of their color together.  Once all tiles are placed, a turn generally consists of exchanging the positions of any two tiles.  The object is to unify all of one's own tiles into the same country (connected group).  The King protects the tiles in its group (another player can only remove one by swapping it with his or her own King), but can only be moved once for free - after that a penalty must be paid.  The Warrior offers additional movement abilities.

The game was originally published in 1975 under the name Kingdoms.  The version shown, titled The Game of Ancient Kingdoms, was published in 1976.  The rules are nearly identical, with the later version adding the penalty rule for moving the King and a rule for scoring draw games.

In this James Bond game, each player is a special agent with 3 skills (charm, strength and dexterity) with different values. The aim of the game is to defeat the most enemies by beating them in one of the skills (resolved with dice).
The box depicts Timothy Dalton in "License to Kill".

In Bärenspiel, players try to rescue a little bear lost in the great forest. Rolling special dice, players must first construct a map of the forest, find the bear, then help it out of the woods, working together to overcome one obstacle or another. Once the bear is located, players are allowed seven rolls of the dice to get it clear of the forest. If they fail to do so, they lose the game and the bear eats them.

The 2011 AMIGO edition is part of its "Ökologisch + Kooperativ" (Ecological & Cooperative) line of games.

Players attempt to collect money, memberships and material goods to win.

As each player collects more wealth, they move to new areas of the board, which give more lucrative opportunities.

Two-handed contract Bridge.

Rules for playing Bridge against an automated pair of opponents.  Primarily designed for one pair of players to practice their bidding and trick-taking skills.

The goal of each of the players is to be the first to mark off all the symbols in his game triangle.

The players will find that he must use some political strategy at times by advancing the cause of other players in order to make some small gains himself, or still at other times he may conspire with the majority to stop an opponent who has presidential fever, or who is on a steam roller.

This game is basically a card game with a board for scoring.
Guet-Apens is a medieval wargame. It contains quite heavy simulation rules for knights, soldiers, bowmen, etc... and a book of 12 scenarios.

Party-game where players have to answer questions, mime or draw objects with a "limp" pen...

In this party game, players move one of two hippo pawns over an 8-shaped track.The fields they land on determine the task they have to fulfill (for this, they also draw a card) - in most cases, the other players try to guess the word/phrase that was intended: 
- Draw an item with a wobbly pen
- Take a sip of water and gargle the word
- Group acting (together with one or more players they chose)
Other tasks include
- Reading out a text - now everyone in turn has to say a word connecting to the text within three seconds. Players who fail to do that are out of this task round; the last player "standing" receiving points. 
- Rolling a "poker" die. A saxophone means a five point chip and the chance to roll again. When a lemon is rolled, all chips of this round are lost. The player can stop rolling any time.

Each kind of field has its own scoring rules. The first player to score 100 points is the winner.

A letter/word version of Rummikub, players attempt to create long words and score points to win.

Complete words may be placed on the table, or letters can be added to current words. Words already on the table can be broken apart and the letters used to form new words as long as at the end of a player's turn he has added at least one new tile, all letters on the table have been used to form valid, unique words, and the longest new word contains at least one letter from his rack.

In this game the object is to reach a goal at the end of a long track with colored spaces. These colors correspond to the bases of several figures.

At the start of the game each player takes a figure (each has a sports theme - soccer player, race car, etc.) At the start of a turn you may exchange your figure for any that remain free in the middle of the board.

After exchanging or not, a die is rolled and the player moves. After movement the figure may be exchanged again.

Landing on squares that match the base color provide a bonus, while trying to move from squares with a different base color is difficult.

In Juggler's Jam each player is a juggler attempting to perform the best tricks. All actions are based on "confidence" points. You need confidence to play tricks and place new items into your juggling pattern and you gain confidence at the start of each turn by adding the values of tricks and objects you have in your "pattern."

Other jugglers are trying to disrupt your pattern and force to drop your items and start over. Just like in real juggling you have a choice of a few patterns you can juggle your objects in and when an object is in your hand you can invoke any special powers the object commands.

Juggler's Jam is a humorous game for 2-4 players Ages 13 and up designed by Jay Turley.

"The six-man international crew has just dimmed the lights, bid each other a multi-lingual good night, and settled back to dream of gravity on board the International Space Station when the unthinkable happens.  Siren blare, airlocks slam shut, emergency lights flash and it quickly dawns on the crew (not an IQ under 120 among'em) that something has gone horribly wrong.  They quickly realize that the whole station is losing oxygen and that it isn't going to be long before they're all so much unrecoverable salvage."

"The space station is a disaster.  Equipment is strewn about after years of neglect.  Nobody knows what to do.  But then it dawns on them (sharp lads they are) - there is only one escape pod and six of them.  It doesn't take an astrophysicist with a PhD from M.I.T. to figure out that only two of them are going home, and the rest are going to end up Sucking Vacuum."

"Sucking Vacuum is an easy to learn, fast action strategy game for 3 to 6 players.  Players assume the role of the doomed astronauts searching for equipment and struggling to escape the doomed space station.  They must make their way through a randomly assembled map of the International Space Station while fighting off attacks of other players who are trying to escape themselves."

Sucking Vacuum 2nd Edition (titled Ultimate Sucking Vacuum) is an updated version of the Origins Award-nominated game.  Now in full color with a sturdy box, the game features new artwork on the 18 map tiles and 73 die-cut counters.

Gameplay is similar to the original, but the rules have been re-written and revised in a number of areas.  Additionally, the game now includes Tournament Rules and the Alien Incursion variant.

"The official game of the World Championships in Athletics!"

In this game you compete in five different sports: long-jumping, 110m hurdles, javelin-throwing, pole-vaulting, and 1500m.

In each sport your results are measured in meters or seconds, just like in real life, so you have a chance of setting new world record! In addition, you get "result points" in each sport. The better your results, the more points you get. The result points are added up, and the player having the most points after all five sports is the winner! The "super score" - very hard to achieve - is 1000 points or more.

One special feature of the game is that you yourself can influence your results; the outcome is not decided by the dice alone.

So if you're planning to win this official game of the world championships in athletics, it is going to take both skill and luck - just like in real life!

This is a rare Fenno-Alga publication in that, being published to promote the specific sports competition in Helsinki, it does not seem to have a Swedish counterpart at all.

This game is set on the 3-dimensional bridge where the epic struggle between Balrog and Gandalf takes place.

Each player has their own set of cards. Each card has 4 markers on each side, indicating the card's strength. There are also some cards with a special action.

There are four rounds per game, with the winner of each duel moving up the bridge.

Whoever ends up highest after the fourth and final round is the winner.

Lord of the Rings - The Duel is part of the Kosmos two-player series.
